articles.headline: Pain on the Reservation
articles.snippet: Legislation specifically exempted many programs that benefit low-income Americans, but virtually none aiding American Indians were included.
articles.abstract: Legislation specifically exempted many programs that benefit low-income Americans, but virtually none aiding American Indians were included.
articles.lead_paragraph: PINE RIDGE, S.D. — The Red Cloud-Bissonette family needs a new trailer. Frank, who is disabled, and Norma, his wife, are members of the Oglala Sioux Tribe who live on the sprawling grasslands of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. Despite their constant efforts to patch the seams of one of their trailers that was hauled here in 1988, rot and mold continue to climb up the walls.

articles.headline: Boeing 787 Catches Fire in London
articles.snippet: The incident, on a plane with no passengers aboard, took place about seven weeks after 787s returned to the skies after being grounded because of hazards with a new type of battery.
articles.abstract: The incident, on a plane with no passengers aboard, took place about seven weeks after 787s returned to the skies after being grounded because of hazards with a new type of battery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just two months after Boeing seemed to have left the problems with its 787 Dreamliner behind, it suffered another setback on Friday, when a fire broke out inside an Ethiopian Airlines 787 parked at Heathrow Airport in London.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Holder Tightens Rules on Getting Reporters’ Data
articles.snippet: The new guidelines announced by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. would make it harder for prosecutors to obtain calling records from telephone companies without giving news organizations notice.
articles.abstract: The new guidelines announced by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. would make it harder for prosecutors to obtain calling records from telephone companies without giving news organizations notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who has been criticized for the Justice Department’s aggressive tactics in secretly obtaining phone logs and e-mails of reporters as part of leak investigations, announced new guidelines on Friday that would significantly narrow the circumstances under which journalists’ records could be obtained.

articles.headline: Fair Play Measured in Slivers of a Second
articles.snippet: Regulators are taking a second look at media companies that try to generate revenue by charging fees for early access to financial information.
articles.abstract: Regulators are taking a second look at media companies that try to generate revenue by charging fees for early access to financial information.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, Thomson Reuters released the latest University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index, as it does twice a month. But this time was different. As a result of a settlement Thomson Reuters reached this week with New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, a select group of its customers didn’t get the two-second advance release they’d been buying.

articles.headline: Sudden Spike in Gas Prices, but Increases May Be Short-Lived
articles.snippet: Gasoline prices have been rising, mainly because of higher global crude prices that have been gaining because of Egyptian and Nigerian unrest.
articles.abstract: Gasoline prices have been rising, mainly because of higher global crude prices that have been gaining because of Egyptian and Nigerian unrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the summer vacation season picking up, gasoline prices at the pump are inching higher, a seasonal increase that was underscored by an unusual one-day bump on Friday of 3 cents a gallon.

articles.headline: Author’s Views on Gay Marriage Fuel Call for Boycott
articles.snippet: A boycott campaign against the coming film “Ender’s Game,” prompted by the anti-gay views of the author of the novel that inspired the movie, has suddenly gained traction.
articles.abstract: A boycott campaign against the coming film “Ender’s Game,” prompted by the anti-gay views of the author of the novel that inspired the movie, has suddenly gained traction.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At last count, 667 people, give or take, have screen credits on “Ender’s Game.”

articles.headline: Rules for Reverse Mortgages May Become More Restrictive
articles.snippet: The Federal Housing Administration wants to require borrowers to undergo a financial assessment, and it may also factor in their credit scores.
articles.abstract: The Federal Housing Administration wants to require borrowers to undergo a financial assessment, and it may also factor in their credit scores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many baby boomers will need to consider how their homes — and the value locked inside — will help finance their retirement years. Reverse mortgages, which essentially allow people to use their home as an A.T.M., could become an integral part of many retirees’ financial plans, especially those who are short on cash but do not want to move.

articles.headline: Twitter Yields to Pressure in Hate Case in France
articles.snippet: Twitter has agreed to identify several users who posted anti-Semitic comments on its service, and whom French authorities are seeking to prosecute for violating that country’s anti-hate laws.
articles.abstract: Twitter has agreed to identify several users who posted anti-Semitic comments on its service, and whom French authorities are seeking to prosecute for violating that country’s anti-hate laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter, which has assiduously branded itself as an advocate of free speech, has agreed to identify several users who posted anti-Semitic comments on its service, and whom French authorities are seeking to prosecute for violating that country’s anti-hate laws.

articles.headline: Syrian Rebel Infighting Undermines Anti-Assad Effort
articles.snippet: Rebel factions in Syria are attacking each other in a series of kidnappings, killings and beheadings, as competition for recruits, weapons and the right to define the character of the future state boils over.
articles.abstract: Rebel factions in Syria are attacking each other in a series of kidnappings, killings and beheadings, as competition for recruits, weapons and the right to define the character of the future state boils over.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Competing rebel factions in Syria are increasingly attacking each other in a series of killings, kidnappings and beheadings, undermining the already struggling effort to topple President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Bankers Are Balking at a Proposed Rule on Capital
articles.snippet: Several regulators want to raise the percent of capital that big banks must have on hand to cover losses. But get ready for an onslaught of industry lobbying against the plan.
articles.abstract: Several regulators want to raise the percent of capital that big banks must have on hand to cover losses. But get ready for an onslaught of industry lobbying against the plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: OUR nation’s largest banks have grown accustomed to regulators who are respectful, deferential and mindful of these institutions’ needs and desires. So, last week, when federal financial overseers unveiled a potent new weapon against too-big-to-fail banks, it seemed as if — just maybe — the winds in Washington were shifting.

articles.headline: No Six-Figure Pay, but Making a Difference
articles.snippet: The Venture for America program offers jobs in start-up companies that aren’t the usual magnets for recent college graduates.
articles.abstract: The Venture for America program offers jobs in start-up companies that aren’t the usual magnets for recent college graduates.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOME people might look at what Brentt Baltimore did and shake their heads in disbelief. Last year, Mr. Baltimore, a graduate of Claremont McKenna College in California who majored in economics and finance, turned down a six-figure job at a Los Angeles area hedge fund. Instead he took a $33,000-a-year position at a venture capital firm in Detroit. This, even though he has about $38,000 in student loan debt.

articles.headline: Has Patent, Will Sue: An Alert to Corporate America
articles.snippet: The number of patent-infringement lawsuits has soared, partly because of Erich Spangenberg. His firm has sued 1,638 companies in the last five years.
articles.abstract: The number of patent-infringement lawsuits has soared, partly because of Erich Spangenberg. His firm has sued 1,638 companies in the last five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re a corporate executive, this may be one of the last sentences you want to hear: “Erich Spangenberg is on the line.” Invariably, Mr. Spangenberg, the 53-year-old owner of IPNav, is calling to discuss a patent held by one of his clients, which he says your company is infringing — and what are you going to do about it?

articles.headline: Pitfalls Abound in China’s Push From Farm to City
articles.snippet: Even a showpiece project in Shaanxi Province shows flaws in China’s urbanization drive, including high electricity costs and a lack of jobs in the new towns.
articles.abstract: Even a showpiece project in Shaanxi Province shows flaws in China’s urbanization drive, including high electricity costs and a lack of jobs in the new towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: XI'AN, China — Li Yongping sat in a darkened conference room, his face illuminated by an enormous map of southern Shaanxi Province projected on a wall-size screen. He nodded to an assistant and the screen split: the province on one side and a photograph of a farmer on the other.

articles.headline: Nations Buying as Hackers Sell Flaws in Computer Code
articles.snippet: Governments pay hundreds of thousands of dollars to learn about and exploit weaknesses in the computer systems of foreign adversaries.
articles.abstract: Governments pay hundreds of thousands of dollars to learn about and exploit weaknesses in the computer systems of foreign adversaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the tiny Mediterranean island of Malta, two Italian hackers have been searching for bugs — not the island’s many beetle varieties, but secret flaws in computer code that governments pay hundreds of thousands of dollars to learn about and exploit.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: A Pill Available in Mexico Is a Texas Option for Abortion
articles.snippet: With passage of a measure that may shut down most abortion clinics in Texas, women could turn to “abortion pills” without medical supervision.
articles.abstract: With passage of a measure that may shut down most abortion clinics in Texas, women could turn to “abortion pills” without medical supervision.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — At the Whole Woman’s Health center here, a young woman predicted what others would do if the state’s stringent new abortion bill approved late Friday forces clinics like this one to close: cross the border to Mexico to seek an “abortion pill.”

articles.headline: Remark by Obama Complicates Military Sexual Assault Trials
articles.snippet: In a dozen cases since the president called for prosecution and punishment, judges and lawyers have said his words were an “unlawful command influence,” tainting trials as a result.
articles.abstract: In a dozen cases since the president called for prosecution and punishment, judges and lawyers have said his words were an “unlawful command influence,” tainting trials as a result.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama proclaimed that those who commit sexual assault in the military should be “prosecuted, stripped of their positions, court-martialed, fired, dishonorably discharged,” it had an effect he did not intend: muddying legal cases across the country.

articles.headline: Zimmerman Is Acquitted in Trayvon Martin Killing
articles.snippet: A six-woman jury accepted self-defense as justification for the death of Trayvon Martin, 17, by George Zimmerman in a Florida shooting that ignited a national debate on racial profiling and civil rights.
articles.abstract: A six-woman jury accepted self-defense as justification for the death of Trayvon Martin, 17, by George Zimmerman in a Florida shooting that ignited a national debate on racial profiling and civil rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANFORD, Fla. — George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, igniting a national debate on racial profiling and civil rights, was found not guilty late Saturday night of second-degree murder. He was also acquitted of manslaughter, a lesser charge.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Cara Buckley

articles.headline: Zimmerman Is Acquitted in Killing of Trayvon Martin
articles.snippet: A six-woman jury accepted self-defense as justification for the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, 17, by George Zimmerman in Sanford, Fla., last year.
articles.abstract: A six-woman jury accepted self-defense as justification for the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, 17, by George Zimmerman in Sanford, Fla., last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANFORD, Fla. — George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, igniting a national debate on racial profiling and civil rights, was found not guilty late Saturday night of second-degree murder. He was also acquitted of manslaughter, a lesser charge.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Cara Buckley

articles.headline: Prayer, Anger and Protests Greet Verdict in Florida Case
articles.snippet: Lawmakers, clergy members and demonstrators described the decision not to convict George Zimmerman on any counts in the death of Trayvon Martin as evidence of endemic racism.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers, clergy members and demonstrators described the decision not to convict George Zimmerman on any counts in the death of Trayvon Martin as evidence of endemic racism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The acquittal of George Zimmerman in the death of Trayvon Martin reverberated from church pulpits to street protests across the country on Sunday in a renewed debate about race, crime and how the American justice system handled a racially polarizing killing of a young black man walking in a quiet neighborhood in Florida.

articles.headline: N.S.A. Leaks Revive Push in Russia to Control Net
articles.snippet: Even before Edward J. Snowden arrived in a Moscow airport, Russia had been pressing for greater access to social networking and e-mail data.
articles.abstract: Even before Edward J. Snowden arrived in a Moscow airport, Russia had been pressing for greater access to social networking and e-mail data.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, fled the United States saying he did not want to live in a surveillance state.

articles.headline: After Goldman and Before Trial, a Global Education for Fabrice Tourre
articles.snippet: After taking a leave from Goldman Sachs, Fabrice Tourre worked as a volunteer creating business plans for farmers in Rwanda, where he was known as “Breezy.”
articles.abstract: After taking a leave from Goldman Sachs, Fabrice Tourre worked as a volunteer creating business plans for farmers in Rwanda, where he was known as “Breezy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Fabrice P. Tourre is best known as “Fabulous Fab,” the former Goldman Sachs trader whose e-mails about the mortgage crisis became a symbol of Wall Street hubris and will now highlight the government’s case against him. As the economy was on the brink of collapse, e-mails show Mr. Tourre joked to a girlfriend that he sold toxic real estate bonds to “widows and orphans.”
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Ben Protess

articles.headline: In Battle Over Dell, a Founder Hopes to Reclaim His Legacy
articles.snippet: Michael Dell wants to take his company private and retool it without quarterly earnings pressure. After Dell missed the shift to mobile, he has his work cut out for him.
articles.abstract: Michael Dell wants to take his company private and retool it without quarterly earnings pressure. After Dell missed the shift to mobile, he has his work cut out for him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael S. Dell is fighting a battle over a company that many say is doomed.

articles.headline: Why Barnes & Noble Is Good for Amazon
articles.snippet: Having a bookstore in your neighborhood, as opposed to one that is bookmarked on your browser, is an invitation.
articles.abstract: Having a bookstore in your neighborhood, as opposed to one that is bookmarked on your browser, is an invitation.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday night in Clifton, N.J., Barnes & Noble was a way station, a third place between work and home where people sought respite and diversion. With its high ceilings, wide aisles and a large Starbucks, it is the kind of retail outlet that gives big-box stores a good name.

articles.headline: With a Royal Baby Due, News Outlets Are on High Alert
articles.snippet: The birth of the child, whenever it happens — any day now, if the tabloids are to be believed — will be a spectacle unlike any other in the modern media age.
articles.abstract: The birth of the child, whenever it happens — any day now, if the tabloids are to be believed — will be a spectacle unlike any other in the modern media age.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ask television news executives how long they have been planning for the royal baby’s arrival, and they’re liable to answer with a joke: nearly as long as Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge have been.

articles.headline: Attention, Shoppers: Store Is Tracking Your Cell
articles.snippet: Using video surveillance, and signals from shoppers’ cellphones and apps, retailers are tracking customers’ behavior and moods.
articles.abstract: Using video surveillance, and signals from shoppers’ cellphones and apps, retailers are tracking customers’ behavior and moods.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like dozens of other brick-and-mortar retailers, Nordstrom wanted to learn more about its customers — how many came through the doors, how many were repeat visitors — the kind of information that e-commerce sites like Amazon have in spades. So last fall the company started testing new technology that allowed it to track customers’ movements by following the Wi-Fi signals from their smartphones.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Airlines Confident in Boeing’s 787, but Doubts Linger
articles.snippet: Unless the cause of the Heathrow fire is pinpointed quickly, the airline industry could once again find itself in a delicate spot of balancing passenger safety with high financial stakes.
articles.abstract: Unless the cause of the Heathrow fire is pinpointed quickly, the airline industry could once again find itself in a delicate spot of balancing passenger safety with high financial stakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Boeing and its regulators, it’s like déjà vu.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: No Quick Impact in U.S. Arms Plan for Syria Rebels
articles.snippet: The plan calls for the C.I.A. to supply only small arms, and only to a limited segment of the opposition; the actual numbers are unclear.
articles.abstract: The plan calls for the C.I.A. to supply only small arms, and only to a limited segment of the opposition; the actual numbers are unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A month ago Obama administration officials promised to deliver arms and ammunition to the Syrian rebels in the hope of reversing the tide of a war that had turned against an embattled opposition.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and Erin Banco

articles.headline: Bangladesh Pollution, Told in Colors and Smells
articles.snippet: A deadly building collapse brought the dangers of Bangladesh’s clothing manufacturing to world notice, but the environmental destruction is taking a daily toll as well.
articles.abstract: A deadly building collapse brought the dangers of Bangladesh’s clothing manufacturing to world notice, but the environmental destruction is taking a daily toll as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVAR, Bangladesh — On the worst days, the toxic stench wafting through the Genda Government Primary School is almost suffocating. Teachers struggle to concentrate, as if they were choking on air. Students often become lightheaded and dizzy. A few boys fainted in late April. Another retched in class.

articles.headline: In Zimmerman Case, Self-Defense Was Hard to Topple
articles.snippet: George Zimmerman had the power of self-defense laws on his side, and was helped by a spotty police investigation and prosecutorial missteps.
articles.abstract: George Zimmerman had the power of self-defense laws on his side, and was helped by a spotty police investigation and prosecutorial missteps.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANFORD, Fla. — From the moment George Zimmerman held up his arms and told the police that he had shot Trayvon Martin, one fact was undisputed: an unarmed black teenager lay dead.

articles.headline: Glaxo Used Travel Firms for Bribery, China Says
articles.snippet: Fictitious conferences and sham expense receipts provided the money to pay off doctors, hospitals and government officials, the authorities said.
articles.abstract: Fictitious conferences and sham expense receipts provided the money to pay off doctors, hospitals and government officials, the authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Earlier this year, the authorities here began looking into suspicious activity involving a Shanghai travel agency that was rumored to have huge revenue but few bookings.

articles.headline: Senate’s Leader Sets Showdown Over Changes to Filibuster
articles.snippet: Senators emerged from a closed-door meeting saying  they were confident an agreement could be reached Tuesday to end the standoff over a change to filibuster rules, though no deal had been struck.
articles.abstract: Senators emerged from a closed-door meeting saying  they were confident an agreement could be reached Tuesday to end the standoff over a change to filibuster rules, though no deal had been struck.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid of Nevada took a defiant and uncompromising stand on Monday before a showdown on the future of the filibuster, saying that Republicans must stop blocking executive branch nominations or he will try to change rules to “save the Senate from becoming obsolete.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker
